If you have anxiety, depression, or fatigue, you can cure them naturally.

Most mainstream fixes are temporary. But, if you find the root cause—permanent healing is inevitable.

Here is the absolute best way to heal yourself without pills: 🧵 https://t.co/Zv4xVPO4FP
As a therapist, Somatic Stress Overload is public enemy #1.

It causes 90% of my client's mental health problems.

In this thread you will learn:
• What it is
• How it impacts your health
• How to heal from it naturally

Let's dive in ↓
Somatic Stress Overload happens when your body stores too much physical & emotional stress without releasing it.

It triggers a constant rush of the stress hormone cortisol...

Pushing your body 'in-n-out' of freeze and survival states without ever achieving full relaxation.

Based on your most common emotions, see where you spend most of your time ↓
The stored stress wreaks havoc on both your mind and body:

• Constant fatigue and low energy
• Trouble sleeping or staying asleep
• Mood swings, anxiety, or depression
• Difficulty thinking clearly or concentrating
• Altered gut microbiota & increased blood pressure

They are all caused by accumulated somatic stress.
Imagine your body as a backpack, every stressful event is like a stone that gets added to it.

Over time, as more stones accumulate, the backpack becomes heavier.

Normally, if you remove a stone, the weight would lighten.

But with Somatic Stress Overload the stone goes away, but the backpack doesn't get any lighter.... the stress remains stuck in your body
As humans, we've unknowingly suppressed our body’s natural ability to release stress.

Society has conditioned us to 'push through,' disconnecting us from our own healing instincts.

Anxiety, depression, and fatigue aren’t personal failures—they’re your body’s natural response to a culture that tells you to ignore your needs...
But, there's good news...

The days when depression, anxiety, and fatigue had no cure are over.

You can combat Somatic Stress Overload with one skill... discharging ↓
Discharging

Have you ever noticed how animals shake, tremble, or take deep breaths after a stressful event? It’s their natural way to release excess cortisol.

Humans have the same built-in stress-release mechanism, but we’ve forgotten how to use it.

This is your body's natural defense against anxiety, depression, and fatigue:
Want to see how the stress release works? Watch this video.

You'll see my body in action, releasing tension through involuntary movements.

What’s fascinating is that these movements are driven by my nervous system, I'm not consciously moving my body.

Notice the smile at the end (it feels like bliss).
The human body has built-in triggers to 'reset' and recover from Somatic Stress Overload.

This field of study is called Somatic Therapy.

It uses natural techniques—combining biology, neuroscience, and psychology—to heal the body from the inside out.
Somatic therapy focuses on the autonomic nervous system (ANS), an area where traditional talk therapy often falls short.

The ANS plays a crucial role in how our bodies respond to stress, trauma, and emotional regulation.

To truly heal from stress, we need to learn how to work with the ANS like a pro.
You can't heal years of anxiety, depression, and stress by thinking your way through it.

The key lies in activating the autonomic nervous system, the body's natural healing mechanism.

Somatic therapy effectively engages the ANS through various techniques, allowing you to release stored tension and trauma.
Based on my years of experience with clients, somatic therapy stands out as the most beneficial healing method available:

• Improved sleep quality
• Boosted energy & vitality
• Healing from past trauma
• Increased mental clarity and focus
• Relief from chronic pain and tension
• Enhanced emotional regulation and well-being

These are the changes my clients consistently report.
If you're ready to eliminate anxiety, brain fog and overwhelm for good...

𝗩𝗶𝘀𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽𝘀 𝗼𝗻 𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝗔𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗪𝗼𝗿𝗸

Previously we discussed how transformers improved natural language processing by introducing self-attention mechanisms and parallel processing capabilities. Now, let's break down the steps visually to understand how transformers process language.

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟭: 𝗜𝗻𝗽𝘂𝘁 𝗘𝗻𝗰𝗼𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴

When a sentence is fed into the model, the first step is to convert the words into numerical vectors that the transformer can understand. This is called Input Encoding, where words are turned into embeddings—dense vectors that represent the meaning of the words.

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟮: 𝗣𝗼𝘀𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗘𝗻𝗰𝗼𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 → 𝗜𝗻𝗽𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝗘𝗻𝗰𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗿

Next, the transformer must recognize the order of words. Since transformers process all words simultaneously, Positional Encoding is crucial. This encoding adds information about the position of each word in the sentence, ensuring that the model understands the sequence in which words appear.

Once the words are embedded and their positions encoded, these vectors are sent into the Encoder. The encoder is a stack of layers where each layer has two main components: the Self-Attention Mechanism and a Feed-Forward Neural Network.

𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝟯: 𝗦𝗲𝗹𝗳-𝗔𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗠𝗲𝗰𝗵𝗮𝗻𝗶𝘀𝗺

At its core, the Transformer consists of two primary components: an encoder and a decoder. Each component is designed to perform distinct yet complementary functions in the processing of input and generation of output.

Within the encoder, the Self-Attention Mechanism comes into play.

The self-attention mechanism is a pivotal innovation within the Transformer model, enabling it to discern intricate relationships within data. It allows the model to weigh the significance of different parts of the input independently of their position in the sequence. For instance, in the sentence "The bill sat on the mat," the word "bill" might have strong connections with "sat" and "mat," helping the model understand context. The self-attention mechanism assigns importance scores to these relationships, allowing the transformer to grasp the meaning across long distances within the sentence.

To achieve this, the mechanism computes three vectors for each input element: a query, a key, and a value. The process involves a dot product between each query and key, followed by a normalization step using SoftMax, and finally, the resulting weights are applied to the value vectors, producing the attention vector. This vector is a representation that captures the contextual relationships within the input.

𝗖𝗼𝗻𝗰𝗹𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻

Transformers and Attention Mechanisms has shed light on the advancements in modelling sequential data. With their self-attention mechanism, they have surpassed traditional models like RNNs and LSTMs in various tasks, particularly in language modeling and text generation.

The importance of attention in Transformers cannot be overemphasized, as it enables the model to weigh the significance of different input tokens and capture long-range dependencies without sequential processing.

My predictions on Industrial RE.

My family owns a moving company that’s 122 years old.

I started a tech company that quotes moving jobs virtually without physically going out to the home. We work the biggest moving companies in the world. We have more data than anyone in the world.

Using this data it was obvious self storage and industrial warehousing was going to explode.
 
We diversified heavily into real estate.

Now real estate is ALL I DO and these are my thoughts.

Self storage will continue to explode. People have a massive amount of stuff (the tech company inventories households) the average weight and peice count of our reports increases every year.

The military, US government and large corporations also pay for moves and storage. This also increases year after year.

Too many reasons to list why self storage is great.

Industrial space is at an all time low vacany rate and prices are at an all time high. 

Basically every tractor trailer on the road is working for someone in industrial space.

This will continue to be the trend.

Simple supply and demand and again not enough people building.

Contractor garages will be on every corner.

These are spaces in between self storage and industrial warehouses.

So many small entrepreneurs need more sqft than self storage and less than industrial warehouses.

Huge opportunity is in contractor garages it’s not so much low vacancy more that it just doesn’t exist in many places but, trust me it will be everywhere.

Many times these 3 can be mixed to derisk and investment.

250k of just self storage is a lot of self storage but 100k self storage,100k warehouse and 50k contractor garages is easily leased.

I have the inside track as I see where people move,what they move,where they are going.

My top 5 tips for bootstrapping a services business:

1/ Nail your Customer

Start small.  Every business goes to 1 customer at a time.  Figure out who the absolute perfect fit is for you.  Who you can sell to, relate to, service.  One vertical, narrow.

Avoid being everything to everyone.

2/ Nail your Offer

Create ONE offer with ONE price.  Be extremely clear with the client what it includes and have a very tight scope.  Ensure that the offer solves a REAL painpoint or problem.  Ensure that it has enough value for the client that they couldn’t “just do it themselves.”

Be In N Out, NOT a diner.

3/ Nail your Delivery

The amount of services businesses that sell the dream and then fall apart in delivery is astounding.  Delivery means: get organized, communicate well, provide deadlines and HIT them, go above and beyond, reduce friction.

If you don’t Deliver, you die.

4/ Nail your Team

Make no mistake: you will live and die by the talent you attract and how well you train.  The easiest way to “solve” delivery is to have amazing people.  People who are: motivated, have high ownership, are curious, strong communicators.

5/ Nail your Margins

>60% gross margins.  That’s your target.  Anything less means you’re likely selling a commodity or you’re underpriced or very inefficient.  I like high-margin targets because they also force you to deliver REAL value.  You better be great at something to put > half the $ in your pocket and still give value to your customers.

Customer → Offer → Delivery → Team → Margins

They all tie together.

Most important, be patient to get it all working like a “McDonalds Franchise,” including REMOVING yourself from it and the service still thrives.  Once that is true, then you scale.

One powerful thing about LLMs is their ability to figure out where to look up data and take actions. This is known as #functioncalling— LLM converts natural language request into API call and/or database queries. Eg, sales rep might ask an AI copilot to cancel an order; the copilot will figure out that this lives inside an OMS application and then invokes the function to cancel. 

The #Trust stakes are higher for accuracy when it involves updating data and invoking actions, so I’m especially proud and excited to share that the new #xLAM-7b model from @Salesforce beats @OpenAI  #GPT-4 in function calling. It comes in close second to @Anthropic’s #Claude 3.5-Sonnet while being *much* smaller and cheaper.

We started a new system in our Sales process and it’s GOLDEN! 

We recently implemented a “quality assurance” call with prospects who we can’t come to terms with on deals. 

Someone from our office (other than the person on the appointment), calls the seller to “check in” on the appointment. 

The call starts casually with: 

- were they on time
- were they respectful 
- etc 

Then we implement one phrase that changes the conversation: 

“Well __ it looks like we weren’t able to get you an offer when you were out to your house. What happened?” 

Then silence……

What happens next? 

They open up about everything! 

Now our inside phone person has just entered a new sales conversation with the seller. 

It’s magical to watch and helps us get a few extra deals that we otherwise would forget about.

He wanted $1.7 million... I offered $2.0 million over 10 years seller financed(he did not call me crazy)

Ok

Let's go back to four months ago when I made a list of all 1,328 towing companies in California and called their owners to see if they were willing to sell.(Towing companies in California have proven to be hard to find for sale.)

While calling, I got a lot of "Fuck YOU, WE ARE NOT FOR SALE!" some mentioned they had not thought about it politely, and in some others, I could not pass the gatekeeper and get to the owner.

After about a month, a broker connected me with an off-market deal based in Fresno, California ( 4 hours away from where I am based).

I called the owner, we spoke, and down the road, we met in person for me to tour his towing yard and learn more about the business.

The owner is really freindly has owned the business for almost 25 years and ready to retire... he even owns the land the business sits on and goes on lake cabin trips 3 days a week.. What a lovely life

Okay back to the deal ... here are some details

Purchase Price:$1,700,000-
EBIDTA: $500,000
Trucks: 8 trucks
6 drivers,2 dispatchers
Private property,rotation ,etc work but refuses to do AAA or motor club work
Rent: $7000 NNN

So it kind off has structure but not yet there to be really hands off 

After we met in person I Offered

$2,000,000 ($300,000 higher than his price) but with a caveat he has to agree to 10 years of seller financing at 4% rate.

He refused but did not call me crazy and came back with an offer.. we negotiated for the next 2 month back and forth on offers etc

Eventually the deal fell through and owner kindoff disappeared (he was worried about the huge tax paycheck he will have to pay)

lots of lessons learned some are:
1. don't get attached to a deal
2. continue your search while in DD
3. why not shoot for the moon on your first offer
4. how to do financial modeling..
5. Find a deal  closer to where you live

now what you ask? onto the next one 

So if you have/know off a company in these sectors in southern california: towing companies, medical transportation, home services, collision centers, pest control, hood cleaning, and niche manufacturing for SALE please reach out to me( i might be able to offer $5,000 if you help me find the right deal and we close)

Finally thank to @Mikethelummox @msaskin @sbabmarks and @haboosheh for the advice on this deal and insight

Last year, I read @Turnaroundartst's book on turnarounds and it was all i could think about for a few months

one of my channels is corporate closures/layoffs/bk/etc

maybe one day I'll score an operating business this way, but for now it's a channel for real estate collateral
@Turnaroundartst Anyways, back to the story

I got a notification that Rogers Corporation, a specialty engineered materials company, what shuttering their Connecticut location

I quickly dug in and found out they had some nice industrial property

181,000 sqft on almost 10 acres
@Turnaroundartst Now if you know me, you know what's coming next

I went to see if they had a mortgage

They did

BUT IT HAD BEEN PAID OFF A FEW YEARS EARLIER

This meant the deal was going into my "too annoying to bother with" bucket
@Turnaroundartst There was probably a dance to be done to get the real estate at a great basis

But i'm not a big dancer and besides Rogers is a big publicly traded company

They would probably hire CBRE to do their real estate dispo and call it a day https://t.co/rhdZKpy2le
@Turnaroundartst To put it mildly, I was very, very wrong

Enter Cedric Glasper (or I as call him, the Rubber Baron)

I checked up on this deal months later and quickly noticed it had traded

for DRUMROLL...

less than 800k or $4 per square foot!!!!!

absurd
@Turnaroundartst Such an outrageously cheap price, I knew something was up

I tried to confirm it with land records, but they had consideration marked at $1.00 https://t.co/lYG06rJnz3
@Turnaroundartst Luckily, I know a trick for this:

Sometimes they stamp the conveyance tax amount on the deed and you can back into purchase price using that

BOOM

absolute steal confirmed, this Sage River Holdings LLC had paid around $4 per foot for a lot of well maintained industrial
@Turnaroundartst Now the next logical question: who was Sage River Holdings?

I hopped over to the Secretary of State to find out the mastermind behind this LLC

That was where I found him: Cedric Glasper of Mechanical Rubber

https://www.mechanicalrubber.com/about-us/our-team/cedric-glasper/
@Turnaroundartst After reading through his impressive biography and charitable involvement it dawned on me

Mr. Glasper scooped industrial real estate at a comical basis

but that wasn't even the most impressive part

he probably got the operating business FOR FREE
@Turnaroundartst And not only that, he saved 61 jobs in the process https://t.co/0hkOwmBH84
@Turnaroundartst Mr. Glasper has been rolling up unloved northeast materials companies since 1995

while I haven't met him, I admire his dedication to his craft

He knocked my socks off with his basis, but also saved the livelihoods 61 employees and their families

very impressive
@Turnaroundartst There's so many cool nuggets in this story, but here are some that stick with me:
@Turnaroundartst - operators don't have to care as much about flows
- anything can happen if you're in the game
- the best deals come from uneconomic sellers
- track record can beat out price
- don't overestimate others
- don't underestimate yourself
@Turnaroundartst If you liked this little data-driven dive give me a like/follow/RT

We launched a Tree Care business in June

Last month we did $9.9k in profit!

By the end of this month we will have a 2nd location and STILL do about $10k in profit

Here's how we do it
-

September Numbers

Revenue:   $33,308 (Goal was $30k)
Gross Margin:   44.3%
Net Income:   $9,903
Net Income Margin:   27.3%

October Projections

Revenue:   $48,746
Gross Margin:   44%
Net Income:   $9,505
Net Income Margin:   19.5%

1. First WHO then WHAT

@mhp_guy and I created cofounders as a way to scale ourselves and work with rad people

We have a running list of hundreds of potential ideas that has grown over the years. Some are GREAT. Others SUCK!

Our framework is pretty simple when filtering ideas:

     - Do either of us have domain expertise?
     - Can we launch with less than $5k?
     - Will it cash flow within 6 months AND with an investment of $25k or less?
     - Is it a "7 day baddie", meaning is it an idea that we are still as excited about a week later?

We now spend hundreds of hours finding cofounders to launch businesses with (16k applicants and counting)

Our motto is "First Who, then What"

If we look for fit FIRST, we know we will find the right opportunity to work on together

Once we find a cofounder, we give them the list and ask them to narrow down their interests

I have seen @girdley talk about this a number of times. The idea has to be our idea, not your idea

It wont work otherwise

This is how we found James and launched FTC

James has absolutely CRUSHED the launch. We feel lucky to have found such a humble, hardworking and action oriented person to partner with

A sample of some of our texts

2. Maniacal focus on Customer experience

Many of the ideas and industries we focus on are old school businesses with underutilized tech

I just described MOST manual services business

These are typically:
     - High touch
     - Low barrier to entry
     - High trust (they have to trust you)

This means you MUST focus on reputation from day 1

If you:
     - Are hyper responsive
     - Ask for (and get) reviews
     - Do things that others wont (come out for a quote same day)
     - Are pleasant

You WILL grow

Its that simple

3. Control what you CAN control

James has done a great job of worrying about what he CAN control and moving on from what he cant

Things he CANT control:
     - The weather
     - Online leads (in the beginning)
     - Zelle, Venmo and other online payment limitations

Things he CAN control:
     - Proactively building Contractor relationships
     - Creating a Brand and Reputation
     - Having 3 or 4 payment methods for crews

He has worked his BUTT off and dealt with every curveball thrown his way. Especially the difficulties and limitations of Zelle, Cash App and Venmo when working with crews 🤣

4. Hard Work

James spent the first 10 weeks (2.5 months) working 70 hour weeks and generated....

$11,087

This week alone we will do $11,005 (and we still have 2 more days to add to it!) 

It takes time to get the flywheel going
- -

Some other highlights

In September we:
     - Got LSA approved!
     - Got PPC dialed in
     - Upgraded our Jobber account
     - Added 3 new crews into the mix
     - Had multiple people reach out to start new locations

In October we:
     - Are training someone to open a new location
     - Are focused on documenting our systems and processes to scale
     - Will hire our first administrative position

If you found this interesting and want to follow along, give me @CoFoundersNik and my partner @mhp_guy a follow

See you next month!

“How the heck do you manage 40+ businesses?”

I get asked a lot. 

Here are my 5 “hacks” for managing dozens of businesses 👇

I just signed 2 MORE clients for $18k! 🥳

From $0 to $38k revenue in 4 months.

Here's my exact process for running a high-ticket MVP agency with AI laid out for you. THREAD BELOW https://t.co/M4XDj9c4Li
1/ Project Planning with AI
Write your entire PRD in ChatGPT first. Include: User stories, database schema, API endpoints, tech stack decisions, UI component list. Pro tip: use the prompt "Act as a senior technical PM, help me plan {project type}"
2/ Mastering UI with v0
Go to http://dribbble.com/tags/dashboard. Pick 3 similar designs you like. Feed them ALL to v0 in one prompt.  Actual prompt I use: "Create a dashboard layout similar to these references, with {specific features}". This 10x's the output quality.
3/ Cursor AI Workflow
The game changer: Customizing Cursor to your stack.  I store my best prompts and tech stack context in .cursorrules. This helps Cursor understand your patterns and preferred solutions. Result? Features that took days now take hours.
4/ Project Management That Sells
Set up your Notion workspace: http://notion.so/templates/project-tracker. Key sections: Weekly goals (not daily), blockers, upcoming features, client todo's. Clients check this 24/7. Trust me.
5/ The 4-Week Timeline
Week 1: Planning + Design. Week 2-3: Core Features. Week 4: Polish + Launch. The secret? Show a working demo by day 8. Even if basic, it builds massive confidence.
6/ Quality Control
Before each client demo: Manual testing of core flows, mobile responsiveness check, performance optimization, browser compatibility. Small details win big clients.
7/ Launch Framework
Before launching, set up: Custom admin dashboard, simple analytics, error monitoring (built-in with Vercel). Show clients their user growth. They'll be hooked.
8/ Growth Systems
Create a Notion database of: Winning proposals, code snippets, client presentations, common features. Each project makes the next one faster.
The reality?

You don't need a huge team to build 5-figure MVPs.

You need:
- The right AI tools
- Solid processes
- Clear communication
- Predictable timelines

From $0 to $38k in 4 months.

Want more agency building threads? Follow along 🚀

DMs open for questions about any of these systems!

I'm shocked why people are not using GPTs for productivity.\n\nHere are 10 GPTs to do a week’s work in 1 hour: https://t.co/qM4UQU3SyC

I am at least 3-5x more productive using ChatGPT to code.

Not only am I faster writing code I'm familiar with, but I've even shipped apps in tech stacks I'd never used before.

Here's my process, the prompts I use, and why it all works:
1. Start in ChatGPT

ChatGPT is really good at the basics and getting setup out of the way.

These steps are the most abundant in its training data, since they're pretty common across projects

My prompt is usually something like: https://t.co/2ThGfQxGWo
"Write a [describe the tech stack] app using [any auxiliary tech like a database]. I need it to [describe the most important requirements]."

For instance:
"Write a Python/FastAPI app using a PostgreSQL database, hooked up with SQLAlchemy. I need to accept HTML requests and write them to the database"

For most of my simple apps, this works pretty well.

I just keep asking it to add new things as I go.

But, for complex apps...
2. Improve your prompt

Sometimes my apps are just a bit too complex.

If you find ChatGPT tripping over itself, you need to ask it to set out a plan first.

This "family" of prompting is referred to as "chain-of-thought" prompting.

Here's an example:
"You are an expert backend developer. Your task is to write a Python/FastAPI app with a PostgreSQL database. The application should accept HTML requests and write them to the database.

Write a detailed tech spec, including user requirements for [your user type goes here]"
But why does this work?

LLMs aren't really a database. They're more like a contextual search engine.

If you want to get good results out of them, you've gotta be specific.

First of all, you're priming it to think like an expert.
That is an oft-overlooked decision!

You could ask it to work quick-and-dirty, by comparison. Sometimes that's what you want. You don't always need complex user authentication in an MVP.

The second main component is asking it to come up with a plan.
People often make fun of the "think step-by-step" type of prompting, but there's a good reason it works.

If I asked you to cook me some soup, you could probably just heat up some chicken broth and call it a day.

Obviously, that's not what you're after.
Rather, I could ask you to cook me soup that I'd find in a five-star French restaurant.

That would prompt you to, first, look up what kind of soup is commonly served in high-end French restaurants.

Once you know that, you can pick one and start executing.
That's *exactly* what happens here.

But, the benefit of "chain-of-thought" prompting is that you're asking ChatGPT to create that specific list of requirements for you!

And the reason that it can do that is that you're asking it to imitate what a pro would do.
In fact, you can see that it fleshes out your whole app for you.

It's creating an entire data model, an API spec, and a lot more.

Even better than that, since it's contextualizing everything together, you can ask it to change certain aspects and those changes will propagate. https://t.co/fTaVH7oa9p
3. Fire up your IDE

Now that we've got a tech spec built, let's get to coding.

Once the tech spec is built, I generally ask it to start building the main component.

This is because context windows are limited, so you're going to need to remind it of its own plan later.
For this app, you might start by asking it to implement all of the necessary endpoints.

I do it this way because, once I hit the 8k token limit, I can copy the whole Python file (or chunks of it) into the prompt and use that as context as I ask it to implement the next bit.
4. Compress your code

Eventually, your project might get so big that GPT-4 starts redoing work it's already done because it forgot.

If this happens, you have a few options:

Option 1: ask it to summarize your files one-by-one and use those summaries in your prompt
Option 2: collapse your code into function headers and use those as prompt context

Option 3 (advanced): embed your codebase and your future queries, and use kNN to pick the right prompt context based on your query automatically.

Options 1+2 usually cut it, though.
5. Get to deployment

Deployment options are endless, and they're changing all the time. It's usually pretty important to be able to read live docs.

I find this is where the browsing capabilities from ChatGPT come in the most handy.
If you've got plugins access, just using the Browsing plugin.

If not, you can use langchain or check out how tools like AutoGPT do it.

If none of these are an option, try scraping the docs, embedding them, and using Option 3 from above!
This is probably overkill if you're using a more mature deployment option.

In that case, just have GPT generate a Dockerfile, nginx configurations, etc. and you're on your way.
Hope you enjoyed this!

Copy-Paste these 21 ChatGPT Prompts to become a top 1% Copywriter:

[ Bookmark to use later ]

Copywriting Techniques

1. Craft a piece leveraging imagery and visual aids to captivate the target audience, helping them comprehend the benefits of [niche/product]. Utilize this information: [insert additional details about your product or niche].

2. Compose a piece incorporating industry-specific jargon to showcase the writer's expertise and comprehension in the field. Employ this information: [insert additional insights about your product or niche].

Customer Avatar

3. Define demographic information (age, gender, location, etc.) of individuals seeking details about the [insert your niche] niche.

4. Outline the education and employment status of those seeking information on the [insert your niche] niche.

5. Explore brand preferences and loyalty among people interested in the [insert your niche] niche.

Niche Information

6. Examine demographics and psychographics of the target audience within the [insert your niche] niche.

7. Address pain points and challenges experienced by the target audience in the [insert your niche] niche.

8. Illuminate the goals and aspirations of the target audience within the [insert your niche] niche.

9. Analyze buying habits and behavior patterns of the target audience in the [insert your niche] niche.

Bullet Points

10. Discover X surprisingly simple ways to enhance your experience with this product: [insert information about your product].

11. Learn how to obtain - for free! - with this product: [insert information about your product].

12. Uncover valuable insights from ___ that can transform your understanding of __ using this product: [insert information about your product].

Copywriting Frameworks

13. Employ the AIDA (Attention, Interest, Desire, Action) framework to create persuasive content promoting [insert information about your product].

14. Implement the PAS (Problem, Agitate, Solution) framework to effectively promote [insert information about your product].

Objections

15. Address the objection "It's too expensive" with this response: [insert additional information about your product or niche].

16. Tackle the objection "I don't have the budget for it" using this response: [insert additional information about your product or niche].

17. Counter the objection "I don't need it right now" with this response: [insert additional information about your product or niche].

Headline

18. Overcome every obstacle effortlessly with these valuable tips for [insert information about your product].

19. Avoid these ___ mistakes that can make you seem foolish when using [insert information about your product].

Testimonial

20. Script for a follow-up phone call to gauge customer satisfaction and request a testimonial after using [insert information about your product].

21. Craft a series of social media posts showcasing positive customer experiences and encouraging testimonials for [insert information about your product].

Blog Posts Framework:

Ad Copy Framework:

Website Content Framework:

"Write a FAQ section for the [Add info] website addressing common questions and concerns using the SCQA (Situation, Complication, Question, Answer) framework."

Landing Pages Framework:

Press Releases Framework:

Video Scripts Framework:

Customer Testimonials Framework:

10 things that I've seen have the highest ROI:

Everyone says:

“Just find an old school industry that runs on fax machines and disrupt it”.

But no one tells you how.

So I will!

Here’s 20 tips/tools you can use to disrupt any old-school industry with tech:

Bookmark this thread like your life depends on it
👇👇
What’s the most impressive AI demo you’ve seen in the past week?

40 life lessons I know at 40 (that I wish I knew at 20):

1. Stop asking for permission

Don’t think: "If only I could get into this great school/company/job, then I could do great work."

You can do great work right now! Build something people want and bypass the gatekeepers.
2. Find the torture that you’re comfortable with

Success in any career requires sacrifice.

So try different paths to find what Seinfeld calls: “a painful thing that you can do for hours that would make others tap out in minutes.”

For example, I love waking up at 6 AM to write.
3. Look for the intersection

Find work that satisfies what you want, what you’re good at, and what the market wants.

If you're in a job that you're good at BUT drains your energy, please keep looking. It's arguably the most dangerous place to be.
4. Just ****ing start

The best way to learn if something will work is to try it.

Don’t waste time making grand plans or thinking, “Someday, I’ll do this.”

Instead, just ****ing start and get real feedback as soon as possible.
5. Ask, “What did I fail at today?"

You've become too comfortable if the answer is “nothing” for days.

I’ve failed at jobs, relationships, and more — they were some of my lowest moments but also where I grew the most.
6. Great relationships are the greatest source of happiness in life

Avoid having a 50/50 mindset with your spouse, give your kids your full attention, and live near your aging parents.

Keep in touch with close friends and show genuine interest in others to make new friends.
Check out the full post below for more on what I've learned about:

- Career
- Health
- Relationships

📌 Get all 40 lessons here: https://creatoreconomy.so/p/40-life-lessons-i-know-at-40-i-wish-i-knew-at-20

The most practical way to make $1M:

Buy a SaaS business and flip it for 4X in 12 months. 

I’ve done this multiple times. 

My exact 5 step blueprint on flipping SaaS businesses for millions 🧵
1. Finding a great SaaS business
2. Approaching the owner with an acquisition offer
3. Financing your purchase
4. Growing the product
5. Selling it
Step 1 - How to find a great SaaS business?

This is a crucial step.

You need to pick the company that you know CAN do well.

Key indicators to look for while selecting: 
1) ARR 
2) Retention/Churn 
3) Competition
Go to http://microacquire.com

Filters you should start from:

✔ $100k ARR
✔ 65% retention
✔ Fewer competitors
✔ A strong value prop (a must have)
✔ Annual growth rate 10%
As I mentioned, this is the most important step.

Go through everything diligently.

Ask for help if you can't make sense of something.

Everything you do from here on is your responsibility.
Step 2 - How to approach the owner with an offer?

If you're on Microacquire, you can send a message to the owner on the platform.

If you find a company not listed on Microacquire, here's what to do:
- Cold DM & email the owner offering to buy their SaaS

Your outreach should seem legitimate. 

It should show that you have the ability to pay.

Include your LinkedIn/Twitter, your current job title, and why you want to buy their business.

For example, here's how I did it - https://t.co/JvmrLT20UJ
Step 3 - Financing your purchase

Tip: Aim for companies above your purchase price.

You can always negotiate it down or rely on seller financing/loans to meet the price.
My rule of thumb: 

Purchase price = 1-3x ARR 

If it's growing fast, you have to pay more. 

3 ways to get the $: 
1) pipe .com 
2) SBA loan 
3) Seller Financing
Go to pipe .com

It allows you to use the company's future revenue to finance your acquisition.

For $100k in ARR, you can get $50k - $85k upfront and pay them later as your customers pay you (expect 1.15x to 1.6x on your principal)
Or you can take an SBA loan (6.5%-10% interest). 

SBA will value the company and offer around 70-90% of their valuation 

You'll have to fund 10-30% of the sale price out of pocket.
Step 4 - How to grow it?

Firstly, make sure you retain your current users.

At least people who are obsessed with your product and can't live without it.

Because of this, now you have an 'Ideal User Persona' you can target in your marketing.
3 ways you should do marketing:

1. SEO
2. Social Media
3. Influencer Marketing

SEO (6+ months)

Because SEO is slow, your rivals likely avoid it, which is precisely why it will be effective for you.

Find relevant keywords and search terms for your ideal users and rank on them.
Use @ahrefs to find a search query that fits this criteria

1) Query is hyper-relevant to the problem your SaaS fixes

2) No big website ranks for this query

3) Has a search volume of >50K
@ahrefs You could become the top-ranked site for a search query and receive 50K visitors a year with as few as 15-20 backlinks.

Once you achieve success for one search term, look for the next one on Ahrefs.

Find terms, build links and repeat 🔁
@ahrefs Social Media (2+ months)

Focus on channels where your ideal user hangs out.

If the SaaS is about helping creators organize their content pipeline, create videos on TikTok and Instagram Reels.

If the SaaS is for businesses to simplify their accounting, use LinkedIn.
@ahrefs Get in your ideal user's shoes and think where they hang out.

If it's Twitter, create infographics, informational threads.

If it's LinkedIn, repurpose whatever works on Twitter.

If it's TikTok, create engaging videos.

Note: Don't just promote your product. Provide value.
@ahrefs Influencer Marketing (3+ months)

Once you execute your social media strategy, you will know for sure which platform gets you best results.

Now, find people in your niche on the platform.

Ask them if they'd want to promote your product.

If the price is reasonable, do it.
@ahrefs For example, a social network for GenZ can use influencer marketing in the following ways:

- Find accounts on Twitter who are young with >10k followers.
- Approach them with an offer.
- Do it at a reasonable price.

Note: Don't make the posts look like promotion. Use your brain.
@ahrefs Step 5 - How to sell it?

There's two ways to go about it:

1. List it on Microacquire
2. Tell people you know that you want to sell (online/offline)
@ahrefs None of this is an exact science, as every business has its nuances. Take care in your approach, 

and remember there is a large % of art that goes into this science, 

so don't be afraid to pave your own path, as this is only a loose framework to show what's possible.
@ahrefs If you found the thread useful, go retweet the first tweet. 

Follow me @jspeiser for more SaaS, startups, and investing.

fields.Content:
Believe me, I would love this too! Here’s why we can’t:

1- our prices are based on frequency, size of building or home, and pests present. Customers would have to be able to identify what they have accurately, pick a plan that may not be sufficient for their situation, and also be honest. I already know people would expect my techs to show up and treat for bed bugs for $150 because that’s what they thought they scheduled. Sounds like 1 star reviews every day.

2- it’s a low ticket item. Route density can be the difference between a profitable day and losing money. I can’t have your wife schedule my 2 pm spot if it’s 45 minutes across town, a 1 hour job, and 45 minutes back. That’s 2.5 hours gone for maybe $150. If she calls in, I can schedule her today or tomorrow on a route where I will have a tech as close to her as possible. Keeps my guys happy and our costs down which means I don’t have to raise prices. 

3- some jobs take 20 minutes and some take a half a day. Customers cant be allowed to just book on my calendar because it says there’s an opening.

4- I can’t afford to spend thousands of dollars on a custom scheduling form that ties into our CRM api for scheduling, asks customers info for signup, sq footage, pest problems, and gives them a quote that they will be mad about when the tech gets there and identifies German roaches are the issue not oriental roaches and the price and service plan are both void. Wastes my time and the customers. 

5- reduces my ability to provide great customer service by upselling supplementary services. 

I’d love if customers could give me money without jamming up my phone lines. Unfortunately, there’s too many logistical problems.
On top of all of this, it takes on average 7 minutes for us to answer the phone call, sell you a service, get your info, and get you scheduled with a payment on file. Just dial our number.

fields.Content:
Want to escape the rat race in 2023 and travel the world?

Start a local business remotely.

Build it into a $100K+/mo money making machine.

Let me show you exactly how I did this 👇

How to become a passive income badass

(And create digital assets that earn while you sleep)

A dead-simple guide to get you started: https://t.co/DD37dHoBJ8

Lack of creativity will kill your business faster than any competitor

Here's how to keep your creatives on point:
1/ Weekly creative review

Every week, review your marketing creatives with the content asset, results, and a perspective on why it worked.

Include both the CEO and the designer. Keep them in the feedback loop.

Here's a snapshot of one of our review slides at Unbloat
2/ Show, don't tell

As a rule of thumb, your design asset should be clear without words.

It should show what you want to sell, as opposed to needing words to tell people about it.

This was one of the best-performing ads for Unbloat https://t.co/1Wr8BhvHKR
3/ Focus on why things work

Between two ad creatives that do well, find a common theme.

Even between assets that seem completely different.

Figuring out why your buyer buys when they do will unlock a whole new perspective on how to design both marketing and product.
4/ Sweat the small stuff.

Virgin Atlantic engraves "stolen from Virgin Atlantic" on their salt and pepper shakers.

At Stockholm's Lydmar Hotel, you can choose your elevator music.

In complex systems, small things can have huge effects. And they can change behaviors
5/ Apply Cialdini's principles

Urgency, reciprocity, scarcity, and commitment are my favorites.
6/ Think tangentially

Logic always leads you to the same place as your competitors.

Most breakthrough insights don't make sense up front.

But trying and experimenting with seemingly irrational ideas can lead to awesome outcomes.

You're only limited by your imagination.
All of this work is done by designer Growth Assistants.

From prepping decks to making the creatives and launching the ads

At Unbloat and 200 clients, like True Classic, DoorDash, and Calm, GAs take on the execution so you can focus on strategy 👇
Design, project management, paid ads - Growth Assistant embeds elite talent from the PH in any marketing role you need.

If you want to grow fast with exceptional talent, book a meeting

First disclaimer:

Audience-building on Twitter is hard.

And then cultivating community is even harder.

If you're up for it, do the challenge at the end. Let's get into it:

These ChatGPT-4o prompts do the work of 7 employees:

(Yes, it's that powerful) https://t.co/tqkvhClPev
1/ Create a lead magnet

use this prompt:

"You are a lead generation expert. create an idea for a lead magnet to attract potential customers for [product/service]. the lead magnet should be valuable and relevant. product details: [product details]." https://t.co/iUhvirfZ1u
2/ Copywriting

The prompt I use:

"You are an advertising copywriter. Write 3 persuasive ad copies. Each copy should highlight the unique selling points, include a strong call to action, and be suitable for use on social media platforms like 𝕏/Twitter. [product details]." https://t.co/TIPnbqs1GN
3/ Email marketing

Prompt I've used for months:

"You're an email marketing specialist. draft a compelling email to promote [product/service]. include a catchy subject line, engaging body, and clear call to action. here's the product info and target audience: [details]." https://t.co/aQ40rIyIsx
4/ Blog posts (mainly SaaS)

The prompt:

"You are a content strategist. Generate 5 unique blog post ideas to promote [product/service], each targeting a specific audience with a brief content description. Product details: [product details]." https://t.co/fAHWpqTqo2
5/ Develop a content calendar

Prompt:

{"username":"David Perell","screen_name":"david_perell","avatar_url":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1759062533078495232/-79hY8EP_normal.jpg","user_id":"240049622","tweet_id":"1770439938623811901","possibly_sensitive":false,"full_text":"25 million people, every single year, download Shaan Puri’s podcast. What has Shaan figured out about storytelling? 

He spilled the beans in our new chat. Here's how he does it:

1. A story is a five second moment of change. A story is not a sequence of events; it's about transformation. Weave in U-turns and unexpected flips. 

2. Write like you talk. Natural, conversational, led by stories.

3. A formula for a great story: Intention + Obstacle. At all moments, the listener should know what the hero wants and what's stopping them from getting there. This one's from Aaron Sorkin, who wrote The Social Network.

4. Work backwards from the emotion you're trying to create in the reader. Then let the structure follow. 

5. Aim for strong reactions. If you can get the reader to widen their eyes, raise their eyebrows, and/or burst out laughing, they will share your work.

6. Don't write to the faceless masses. Write to one specific person. BuzzFeed writers used to write to "Debbie at her Desk," the bored woman at her desk who wanted a 5-minute distraction. 

7. “Likeability” is downstream of vulnerability. The more honestly you share your challenges, the more invested your reader gets. Write your heart out.

8. Don't be the 9,000 IQ guy. Stop competing in imaginary intelligence contests and start telling stories. Big words alienate but tight narratives pull people in.

9. Forget resumes and portfolios. Create a “binge bank” instead. A binge bank is a set of videos or essays that people can binge on. Stack up material so that when people do go down your rabbit hole, they come out the other side a fan.

10. Mere practice gets you nowhere. But intentional practice leads to exponential progress. Always learn from your attempts and make intelligent tweaks on the next try.

11. Comedy is great, but definitely don't make every sentence a joke. 

12. Comedy is a pretty easy way to improve your writing. The essence of all comedy is surprise. Study your favorite comedians. Read books like How to Write Funny and The Hidden Tools of Comedy.

13. For better storytelling, Shaan recommends two books: Storyworthy and Building a Storybrand. 

14. How to make headlines juicy: use specific and odd numbers, focus on the first three words and the last three words, use "you" whenever possible, and know that longer is typically better than shorter.

15. Your writing should only be as long as it is interesting. An uninteresting 20 second reel will fail; an interesting 30-minute essay will win. But you must be honest while gauging how objectively interesting your piece is…in a world with infinite content.

16. Most people think writing is about transferring information but writing is just as much about transferring emotion. Emotion gets people to take action (like, share, buy…). 

The first 40-minutes of this conversation with @ShaanVP is all about storytelling. Then there's an hour more about the genius of Dave Chapelle and how to write with zest.

Boring businesses make the most money.

It's not complicated, yet 99% of people still simp for the fancy ones.

So please...

Buy one of these boring businesses (10 options): https://t.co/DceQQJbKEV
1) Junk Removal.

At least in the US, people have more stuff than they know what to do with.

They'll pay you to take it away for them.

You need a truck and a few friends.

Very simple business model. https://t.co/hohfzxeYJl
2) Tent Rental.

Tent renting couldn't be more simple.

You buy the tents.
You hire a few college kids.
You send them to your locations.

These tents are used for:

- Parties
- Weddings
- Music festivals
- Construction sites

And people pay a fortune for this service. https://t.co/8yfSXqQRbo
3) Ice Vending.

A few notable benefits:

- They print money in high-traffic areas
- Minimal staff requirements (if any)
- Predictable operation costs

And all they do is dispense bagged ice.

Lame, but lucrative. https://t.co/W9GspXRGx1
4) Dumpster Rental.

Has this ever happened to you?

You rent a dumpster, and now everyone wants to be your best friend.

They're too lazy to get their own.

It's a good indication of demand and the business model is very simple. https://t.co/JDtk5bsyLb
5) Pack & Ship Centers.

New businesses are built on the daily.

And a lot of them need a place to send and receive physical packages.

1. Rent a space.
2. Build out your store.
3. Outsource to an operator.

Pack & Ship Centers have great margins. https://t.co/8q1O8aTDgn
6) Solar Panel Installation.

The solar industry is expected to be valued at over $300B by 2030.

A few perks and pros:

- Helps people save on electricity (easy sell)
- Commercial and residential contracts
- You can charge for maintenance

Exciting? No.

Profitable? Yes. https://t.co/QCHZ2indmi
7) Pressure Washing.

Think about this for a second:

You can buy one power washing machine and pay it off with just a few jobs.

Then?

1. You hire a few people.
2. Buy a few more machines.
3. Repeat the process indefinitely.

Pressure-washing companies are cash cows. https://t.co/hhgPmeyhwd
8) Tree Service.

Arborists offer many services:

- Tree maintenance
- Stump grinding
- Tree trimming

Tree services are in constant need and people are willing to pay top dollar. https://t.co/1N9KJvpbY5
9) Street Sweeping.

Most municipalities have standards for the hygiene of their streets.

Using specialized equipment:

They clean streets.
They clean sidewalks.
They clean parking lots.

Many people don't even realize that these businesses exist (so buy one now). https://t.co/vyfSZ2nGqq
10) Pallet Manufacturing

Let me ask you.

Do you enjoy online shopping and same-day delivery services like Amazon?

Well, they need pallets for that.

And I don't see this industry slowing down at all any time soon (or ever). https://t.co/1rPl6JWIrl

I have helped hundreds of agencies scale beyond $1,000,000 a year through the right systems 

Clients did this by following my 8 step roadmap for automating their internal operations 

We charge $2000/mo for this roadmap, but today you will get it for free

A Masterclass Thread https://t.co/QtuNKRbDn5
I have not found ONE single agency that has had elite operations

This  8 step plan will give you the foundation to scale to 9 figures
1-Templitize workflow

The 1st step in building an elite operation is mapping out each step in the operation

From the second a client pays, all the way to a client staying for a year, map out:

>Each step
>The owner
>SOP & training
>Software needs
>Communication workflow https://t.co/GefjhvcbJm
2-SOPs & Trainings

SOPs: Simple set of steps that anyone can follow
Trainings: Complex set up procedures that teach team members how to think

Go back through each step in your workflow and identify which step is in need of an SOP vs a training
For SOPs, following my 5 step framework: https://t.co/ZeqOarsrG8
To learn how to set up effective trainings, review the below thread 

Hint: I've never met anyone in the agency game that knows how to do this
3- Org Chart: Defining Expectations

The purpose of an org chart is not to define who reports to whom (although it does that too)

It is to set CLEAR expectations

An effective org chart will include:

>Responsibilities
>Goals
>KPIs https://t.co/4kHe8bIIZ2
I find most founders struggle with setting KPIs

KPIs are the inputs that lead tot the outputs (Results/goals)

To easily establish KPIs, identify what the quantifiable goals are for each role

From here, write out what the input actions are that lead to the desired results
Example: 

Role: Customer success manager

Goal: Monthly client churn <5%

Inputs:

>Complete a quarterly business review
>Reply to all client slack messages daily
>Introduce client to 3 potential partners monthly
4- Templatize Project Management 

With the combination of steps 1-3, you should easily be able to templatize project management 

What this means:

When we sign a new client, we should be able to copy and paste our template for a new client project management board
Items to be included inside your project management:

>Task
>Client
>Due Date
>Task Owner
>Hyperlinked SOP/Training
>Status (on track, complete, past due)
In addition to project management, we can templatize standard work

Standard work are the input items that must be completed in addition to daily client execution

These are created in step 3 (Org Chart/KPIs)
5- End of Day Reporting: Creating Visibility into Daily Execution

Micro-management can EASILY be irradicated from the world

Every team member should have a mandatory end of day report to submit (we had this at Amazon)

End of day reporting shows if we executed or not https://t.co/qnNwK1Up8R
End of day reporting can be automated through project management or physically submitted through a report

I recommend each team member submit a report daily for added accountability and visibility https://t.co/VzGBHM4U23
Here is a video breakdown of this process:
https://www.loom.com/share/fa9060468f5f468bb63ae311b41ced92
6- Client Dashboard: Track Client Results

A dashboard shows us how our book of business is performing

The #1 reason agencies underperform is due to:

>Lack of visibility
>Lack of accountability
>Lack of contingency planning when we are trending poorly

Dashboards solve for this https://t.co/CUZbbS9oQy
To build a dashboard, follow these steps:

1- Identify all the relevant KPIs we must track per account
2-Set clear goals we aim to hit per client per month
3-Admins input data that cant be tracked via APIs
4-Track results through APIs and automations
7- Operations Meeting

Once we have a functioning dashboard, our teams should be tracking performance on a weekly basis for our accounts https://t.co/ZJbOJic8yt
During the weekly ops meeting, team members update managers on:

>Updates on previously assigned actions
>Targeted performance vs actual performance 
>Plans to turn around under performing accounts

This one process will drastically improve your team performance
8- Training Matrix (Optional Step)

This step is mainly for my larger agencies (we usually have to do this with our 8 figure agency clients) 

A training matrix shows which skills team members do and do not have 

It enables managers to have a plan to develop talent and train https://t.co/5Y0KVEacw6
How to make a training matrix:

1-Identify all the skills that are needed for a role (hard and soft skills)
2-Break the skills into sub-departments
3-Put team members across top row
4-Put all skills down a column

To finish, mark the skills team members do and dont have
The 8 step plan is the foundation to building an elite agency operation

. @wizofecom added 6 new clients within his first month of applying this one process into his agency

3. I don’t believe there is a correlation between investment performance and number of books read.

4. Experience is overrated. It’s important but it’s not a source of competitive advantage. If that wasn’t true, all the great money managers would have their best years in their 60s, 70s and 80s. And we know that’s not true.

“There are 7 traits great investors share that are true sources of advantage because they can’t be learned once a person reaches adulthood. Some of them can’t be learned at all, you’re either born with them or you aren’t.”

00:00 - Intro
00:43 - Why only very few can compound money 20% for their entire career
05:22 - To protect your investment, you need one of these four sources of economic moats that are hard to duplicate
07:59 - Having advantages over fellow fund managers and individual investors
11:12 - 7 traits that can’t be learned yet true investors who end up compounding at 20% or 25% over their careers ALL have in common

Welcome to This Is Bizness: The Sourcely One 
My First Bizness Acquisition: an AI student tool with $500 MRR for $4k! (Breakdown No. 17 btw🤪) https://t.co/RVigpckJPL
I am excited to announce that we are the new owners of @sourcelyai, an innovative AI-powered source finding tool that makes research easier for students. We are committed to building on the foundation laid and taking Sourcely to even greater heights (MRR!).
Wait…. We? Yessir! 
I bought this business with a partner: @elmanmansimov He’s worked with Deepmind and Google before and currently working at AWS. He has his Ph.D. in AI from NYU, is an AI GOAT, and will be the technical genius behind Sourcely going forward  🧠
@elmanmansimov How it all started 🤩

My OG tweet: https://t.co/Arp1GlKYNA
How it's going now: 

Me being the young savvy business genius I am, easily convinced him to partner up 😉. 
Fast forward to a month later on 22 May, we closed the deal for Sourcely at $4,000 (8x multiple of $500 MRR).
Why now?

It was a great price for us mainly because college had just ended for the summer and we suspected many users would churn over the next few weeks. The old owners also really wanted to sell 🤷
How did we find Sourcely?

Originally on @micronsio but had just received an offer for $7,000, but the price was too high. Then I came across them again on @acquiredotcom at a lower price. Quickly finished the deal after for $4,000 with Elman and I both buying in.
Why did we buy Sourcely and our future goals?

We bought it because we recognized the potential that the site had since it was at a decent MRR through organic traffic and getting users with a subpar landing page. By optimizing and adding more features we could provide more value.
As a student, I have dealt with similar problems many times so feel I have a good idea of the market, its problems, and a network to act as initial channels of distribution. You will see building for students, as a student be a common theme around here 😉
In the next 12 months, we hope to 10x Sourcely to $5,000 MRR before evaluating a sale at 4x $60k ARR= $240k (Recent precedent for this) 
Our goal with Sourcely is to help students discover credible sources for their research papers and essays easily.
We believe that with the right tools, students can excel in their academic pursuits, and that's why we are committed to ensuring that Sourcely remains useful, relevant, and up-to-date with technology. 

This is why we want YOU to vote for the next tool Sourcely creates:
How are we going to turn $4k → $240k?

First order of business is to optimize everything -> improve conversion rates and traffic. Includes remaking website with better copy, landing page, and instructions for the tool since many users input essays incorrectly into the chatbot.
Along with this, we will begin implementing aspects of SEO through a blog and promoting more seriously on socials. Eventually, we will experiment with pricing a bit as we add a pay as you use token pricing system to complement our current monthly subscription.
The Big Picture
The dream for http://Sourcely.net is to become the go-to essay writing tool for students.

I made a chart of Sourcely's larger vision and planned features rollout.
I had fun with this, it really reminded me of my why: just to build and have fun with it :) https://t.co/xBcWlmP92F
Take a minute to try @sourcelyai to see how convenient and quick it is. Whatever you need to find credible sources for an essay, Sourcely has got you covered 😉 
Best of all, it's soooo easy to use, just input your essay and let the AI search Google Scholar for relevant sources.
For those who made it this far, a little sneak peek 🫶: 
There are obvious synergies with @Eleven_59_ with similar target markets so this will essentially be the first Eleven59 tool for students, putting the AI in http://eleven59.ai to good use 🫡
Thank you so so much for taking time out of your busy day. I appreciate and love every single one of you 😊

Alrighty see you guys next week 🖖

A YouTube insider just EXPOSED the algorithm.

Everything you know is wrong.

Here's what he revealed: 🧵
Monetization? Irrelevant. The algorithm doesn't even see it. It's all about viewer satisfaction.
Revenue goals for the recommendation team? Zero. They've literally tanked revenue to improve satisfaction.
Want real feedback? Build a community of fans AND haters. They'll tell you what actually works.
Views matter, but they're not everything. YouTube's watching for who comes back for more.
Pro tip: Your "Audience" tab shows which videos bring in loyal viewers. That's gold.
There's no grand YouTube conspiracy. It's just millions of viewers choosing what they like.
Clickbait is dead. YouTube nuked it by 90%. Now it's all about long-term satisfaction.
Stop chasing views. Start building connections. That's how you win on YouTube in 2024.
Too broad? You're forgettable. Too niche? You're invisible. Find the sweet spot.
Not every video needs to work for everyone. YouTube matches each video to its perfect audience.
The bottom line: Make people glad they clicked. That's what the algorithm really cares about.
Most creators get this all wrong.

Now you know. What are you going to do differently?

If I were starting my career, going to an event, and wanting to stand out in the minds of the new people I meet…\n\nHere’s how I’d do it:

Your business needs a Brand Guarantee

This single idea made one of my greatest businesses, @gocodeup.

It’s grown from an idea to a 60+ person business.

And changed 1000’s of lives.

Here’s how…

—

What is it?

A Brand Guarantee is a contract between you and your customer.

It’s designed to address their biggest fear.

Written as “You get X or we do Y.”

Pretty simple to say. But also hard in practice.

—

How Codeup did it

In Codeup’s case, people come to us looking for a job (and so change their lives).

Their biggest fear would be to spend tuition and get no job.

So, we decided to throw out the rules on how education worked:

“You get a job or we return 100% of your tuition.”

Very powerful!

—

A North Star

In a normal higher ed program, they sell you a degree. Not results.

Codeup could easily fall into that same trap.

But this Brand Guarantee changes everything.

It inspires trust in the company.

But it also shapes the company culture.

—

The power of a Brand Guarantee

Imagine what happens when a student is at risk for a refund.

That’s tens of thousands of dollars walking out the door.

We not only lose the tuition but the money we spent over 5 months for the student.

Each refund equates to most of a salary for an employee walking out the door.

A big deal.

—

Some of my favorite Brand Guarantees

@gocodeup: Get a job or we refund 100% of your tuition

Domino’s Pizza: Delivered in 30 minutes or your pizza is free (no longer used)

@alamofireworks: 100% happy memories or we make it right

(Are there others you like? Reply below!)

—

Making Your Own Brand Guarantee

1) First identify your customer’s greatest fear (talk to them!)
2) Brainstorm possible “contracts” you can write for them
3) Test potential Brand Guarantees with customers and employees
4) Revisit them if they don’t work

—

That’s it.

fields.Content: In a world without venture capital, founders of new companies would need to be rich. Most founders start poor. What you don’t understand is that VCs are in the underdog business.

Posting my first YouTube video on Friday!

I had 2 choices with this:

1. Spend weeks studying the ins and outs of all things YouTube to "feel ready" 

2. Film a Loom video walking through my most popular thread and hit publish

I'll learn 10x faster following the second path.

The simple math on how I got to 10K followers in under 120 days:
- Share information on Twitter as generously as you would with your best friend
- 32 Tweets / day
- 1-2 Threads / day
- 0 missed days, i.e., post 7 days a week

The most important one of all: Be lucky enough to have something to share that is interesting to almost everyone.

It wasn't easy but the formula itself is pretty simple. 🤷‍♂️

TLDR: 
-game to play = AI vs bad game = brick and mortar … 
-infinite scale(great economics) vs limited scale (crap economics)…

Not sure I answer the Q but here’s a rant nonetheless… 

Re: Walmart /CVS … Amazon won that game. 

Key ingredients will stop you…
1. Inventory : supplier price / merchandising / mgmt (really f*ckng hard)
2. Scale matters bc 1. And thus capital intensive. 
3. Tech efficiency matters but helps more bc 2.

Why is the customer going there vs anywhere else vs ecommerce?

-convenience/Immediate needs use cases (main only opportunity / hence grocery still works B&M)
- Price competition is race to bottom
- Location is key (expensive in high density vs rural destination like Bass pro shop)
-Can they get margins to compete on price ( since price checking is so easy)
- scarcity or unique inventory is a possibility but lacks scale … then leverage ecommerce and undermine scarcity to a degree 

Brick and mortar is going out of biz quite a bit (recent ex : Bed Bath & Beyond, Kmart, jc penny , sears). 
So how do you compete : high end or mass market. Target is unique mid market. 

Need supplier distribution and use cases that differentiate…. Inventory strategy is real and hard (sunk inventory costs even w/consignment ).

Consider what brings in customers vs what makes you money. Then how to increase AOV and LTV.

Location: cvs (convenience play)
Low cost : WMT
Brand: Target - their innovation and up scaling w/clothes and products differentiated them 

Hard to find differentiation and compete at scale. 

Luxury with limited inventory is only main sustainable competing models.

Now that inventory with slight delay and price transparency via internet, it’s a losers game for retail.

Warehouse is a different angle and game that’s ok but not the same. 
—-

Agree with @ppcClickShark on game selection.

Game selected = tech

Unlimited capital = higher risk or lower probability 

A) Innovation in tech has the upside to both push boundaries and disrupt biz models 
B) Capital mgmt is better in tech because inventory is tough to manage vs high gross margins + deliver ability (eg build once )—grow much faster due to unit economics vs retail

Compete w/SFDC : this is/has happened with companies eating away at the low end and niches across the ecosystem. 

Most is NOT as strong as it could be. BUT they are acquisitive and gobble up market gaps or successful partners. Ecosystems are powerful—if it didn’t integrate w/SFDC we didn’t buy it. ERPs have the same advantage. 

Sfdc has a challenge of sfdc admin and support. Lack of enough talent and partners. Easier to use solutions can win from that 

The play is be better at one of their features and build into an ecosystem and be easier to use that requires less skilled talent. 

Large companies naturally get clunky, so Innovators Dilemma is the competitive strategy.

And there’s AI… sfdc started rolling out AI w/Einstein and more products coming out. But it’s possible to disrupt if they don’t acquire it first!

Game selection : AI no question BUT it’ll be less defensible that what SaaS was even 2 yrs ago! AI is scalable but to a degree less defensible … so ecosystems and platforms who get scale early, win.

How to go from $0 to $10k/mo:

(I applied this to my 20+ startups)
1. Idea.
- easy to build (ideally nocode)
- can be explained in one sentence
- targets a small niche b2b
- it has organic growth potential

Don't ever think: "I'll buy ads to promote it". 
This literally never works.

e.g. http://listingbott.com - get listed on 100+ directories with one click & get backlinks. Tools: unicornplatform + stripe + zappier + uipath + zoho. Niche: busy solo founders. Growth: word of mouth.
2. Validation.
- SEO traffic on keywords
- viral tweet. need no followers. I see such tweets from small accs every day. I've done them myself when I had no followers.
- waitlist (use simple one: https://subscription-page.unicornplatform.page/)
- pre-orders with stripe payment link
3. MVP.
- for directories, launchpads, jobboards, form based apps, info sites just use @unicornplatform, webflow or wix.
- for micro SaaS apps use bubble
- for SaaS use nextjs templates & boilerplates (http://nextjsstarter.com/)
- can't code? go for http://mvpwizards.com
4. Launch
- product hunt, @devhunt_ , uneed, microlaunch.
- betalist, futurepedia...
- http://listingbott.com gonna send you to all free dirs at once
- hacker news, hackernoon, devTo, X, Linkdn, r/sideproject,
5. Marketing.
- SEO (run @seobotai from day one, cuz it takes time)
- buildInPublic on X
- search for reddit/X posts on your topic and reply with your product(avoid looking like spam)
- DM or Cold Email relevant people with a short pitch
- partner up with others for cross linking
6. Paid marketing.
- pay influencers ($100 per post)
- sponsor directories ($100-$300 per banner)
- sponsor small newsletters (e.g. @petecodes )
- buy a directory with relevant traffic to channel it in
7. Fun marketing.
- build a side project for the same audience and place your banner there
- build micro tools on subdirectory of your main site to win seo traffic
- implement pSEO on your main site as subdir
- measure analytics to callibrate actions (http://countvisits.com)
8. Strategy.
- focus on SEO and word of mouth over time
- talk to every single user you have every month
- make product perfect for a small subset of your users
- instead of extending your audience, find more of the same users you made it perfect for
9. Features.
- don't add anything unless several users ask
- try to actually remove features you see nobody is using
- less code, less bugs
- spend more time perfecting existing features than adding new
- your users will fall in love with the product and share with their friends
10. Finale.
- once users start sharing it with their friends, the final goal is achieved. 
- the growth will be on autopilot from now on
- focus all your energy on 
-- more SEO
-- make existing users even more happy

My dad asked: "How can I use ChatGPT/AI in my government contracting business?" 

I riffed with him on how AI/ChatGPT could win more business 🤯 (They write a lot of proposals to win government/state/city contracts):

1⃣ Ask ChatGPT to gather and download all the proposals submitted in the last 5 years specific to the service that he wants to provide. Only include proposals that were for projects that had a total cost of $1,000,000 to $15,000,000. Add additional filters to really narrow down to the contracts that are relevant to your business (many submissions to government contracts are public so they should be easily available, or through a FOIA request which we could automate through ChatGPT too)

2⃣ Ask ChatGPT to summarize the proposals downloaded in table format by showing the # of projects, the project focus, the total project cost, the company submitting the proposal, and the company name's website, the stakeholder on that project.

3⃣ Now I want ChatGPT to write a draft proposal for a new consulting project I'm about to bid on that are similar to the ones I downloaded. Use the won proposals that were previously downloaded & use their fundamental structure and writing style to compose a 50 page draft proposal. Address all the questions outlined in the RFP (request for proposal which details exactly what sections need to be in the draft proposal). Insert additional sections of X, Y, and Z which I know to be extremely important to the consulting project stakeholder. The draft proposal should be in word format so that I can download it for easy editing.

**This is just a single example!** This prompting is NOT possible today (ChatGPT just says go pound sand), but it gives you a sense for what will be possible in a short time period to take  out / amplify entire industries.

Doing steps 1-3 might have cost him $50-$75K in resources, coordination, time, manual drafting and review with his team before AI.

With AI? Now he has a legit draft based on previous winning proposals in minutes. 🔥🔥🔥

For SMBs, what was a 'necessary expense' is now 'waste' if you have the proper understanding of how to use AI.

It goes to the heart ♥️ of...seriously, how are we differentiating ourselves in the world of smarter AI?? Is AI overstated? Time will tell.

Best part is you own multiple businesses, worst part is you own multiple businesses. 

Builder beware… something always going wrong. You gotta be a weird masochist (like me). ;)

Here's a big list of things that don't seem to work, based on the last 20 years of running Tiny:

• Giving an advisor or advisory board free equity to advise a CEO without putting any real skin in the game  and investing their own money (they usually go "thanks for the free equity" and occasionally respond to emails)

• Variable price/cost plus contracts (going over budget = vendor makes more money - natural incentive to go over budget)

• Synergy between two entities, unless they are almost 100% identical and it happens naturally between the two management teams with a clear profit incentive (even then, rarely works)

• Hiring people with traditional finance backgrounds—especially big corporate accounting—as opco CFOs (I see this a ton - first time entrepreneurs in small businesses hire a bean counter when they need somebody who is willing to roll up their sleeves and operate the business alongside them with a financial lens)

• Hiring outside management/compensation/etc consultants (they have no alignment and get paid regardless of the outcome / often incentivized to tell you to change everything so they sound smart / they can't deliver hard news to management because they serve them / "consulting is the art of picking your pocket watch to tell you the time")

• Fractional CFO/finance people vs. in-house finance (you'd almost always pay the same amount just in-housing, except you get 1/20th of their time and attention and they aren't aligned with you)

• Hiring a big company person to run a small or medium company (no scrappiness, used to a big cushy org full of support - usually don't know how to hire, how to do HR, how to incentivize, how to run an actual org, think TOO big)

• Hiring a CEO from a business with X business model (for example, ads) and expecting them to execute Y business model (for example, recurring membership revenue) in your business (people typically keep executing the strategy they know and love/are comfortable with - “to a person with hammer, everything looks like a nail”)

• Expecting a business to disrupt itself or incubate its own “labs” projects (these are usually expensive boondoggles and the innovator’s dilemma typically kicks in “never expect someone to understand something that their paycheck depends on them not understanding”)

• Expecting a CEO to issue dividends vs. horde cash when their incentives don’t align with dividend receiving shareholders (CEOs will often  press to keep as much cash on the balance sheet as possible, unless dividends benefit them as well - you essentially incentivize them to create silly R&D projects or at least project the need for massive cash investment)

There's so many more. Will share as I think of them :-)

Mistral has just released Agents that allows you to easily use and customize their models for your tasks.

1. Access the Mistral platform

If you're new, create an account and log in. https://t.co/QhjkUkiMzW
2. Create a new agent

On the Mistral platform, click "Create an Agent" or “Agent”.

(You can get free credits valid for 15 days). https://t.co/2lSwHkeMNW
3. Configure your agent

This is where you bring your agent to life!

- Model: select your preferred large language model
(Mistral Large 2 is a solid choice for most tasks.)

- Randomness: control how creative your agent's responses are

- Instructions: Give your agent a clear purpose by writing a system prompt.

This is how you guide its behavior (example below).

- Demonstrations (optional): Provide a few-shot example to show your agent how to respond to specific inputs.

This helps it learn and adapt.
Instructions example:

“You're an experienced Google Apps Script developer familiar with automating tasks in Google Sheets.

Write a custom Apps Script that automates the process of sending email notifications whenever a specific cell in a Google Sheet is updated.

The script should trigger an email to a predefined list of recipients, containing the cell’s updated value, the timestamp of the change, and a link to the sheet. Provide comments within the code to explain each section.

Use a clear and informative tone in the comments.”
4. Deploy your agent

Click the "Deploy" button to make your agent live. Choose where you want to deploy it:

- API: to integrate your agent with other applications or services.

- Le Chat: this makes your agent available for direct interaction through Mistral's chat interface. https://t.co/TLeQKvLx09
