SMB Case Study: sales rep compensation structure

Facts:
-Your product/service sells for $1,000 per month recurring
-the gross margins are 50%
-you think the rep can close 4 deals per month in a base case, 2 deals in a low case, 6 deals in a high case
-No G&A additional costs to support
-The customers stay for an average of 3 years
-10% of the customers sign, pay the first month then ghost you

What would you propose as the sales rep compensation structure?

A weird hobby of mine…

I collect great questions.

Here’re 7 favorites I’ve come across recently:
—
#1: What non-traditional things were you doing growing up?

"The thing you do obsessively between age 13 and 18, that's the thing you have the most chance of being world-class at." - Bill Gates

h/t: @cory 
—
#2: What’s something you know you should do but you’re not doing?

The Solomon Paradox: We tend to give better advice than we follow ourselves.

The solution? Talk to your 85-year old self. 

What advice would future you give current you?

h/t: @hormozi
—
#3: What do you believe about X that most people don’t?

Successful companies are built on contrarian truths.

What unconventional beliefs do you have?

h/t: @tferriss
—
#4: Do you have any frameworks for making better decisions?

Most people make decisions without ever thinking about how to make sound decisions.

A similar question: What’s your system for learning?
—
#5: What are your biggest challenges right now?

Most people are unaware of the biggest obstacle in their way.

Every problem you solve presents another one.

What’s your current bottleneck?
—
#6: What is the work that keeps on working for me?

At the end of each day, the ice cream store Ben & Jerry’s has leftover waffle cones.

Instead of throwing them away, they crush them up and create waffle cone chips.

Just like a craftsman leaves sawdust as he makes a chair. Every time you create something, you leave some byproduct.

How can I use my sawdust more effectively?

h/t: @kanekallaway
—
#7: How can I stack the odds in my favor?

Successful people are positioned to win before the game even starts.

There’s always something you can do to improve your position.

h/t: @ShaneAParrish

New to Facebook Ads?

Use these 8 tips:

1/ Don’t launch conversion Ads right away, Your Ad-Account will mostly get disabled.

You need to warm up your Ad-Account.

Launch likes, Reach and Traffic campaigns, in the beginning, to warm it up.

After a week or two launch conversion Ads

2/ simplify - test - iterate

1) Simplify your ad-account structure to 3-5 campaigns.
2) Constantly test new audiences & creatives
3) Learn from the tests & keep making iterations

Works like a charm.

3/ Follow the rule of 3-5.
 
>> Never have more than 3-5 Active Campaigns.
>> Never have more than 3-5 Active Ad-sets in each campaign.
>> Never have more than 3-5 Active Ads in each Ad-set.
 
This rule will help you scale a lot.

4/ Remove the fear of losing money.

If you want to scale you’ll lose money initially.

In testing new Audiences, Creatives & Landing pages.

But those tests will allow you to scale.

It’s like you’re investing for future returns.

5/ 5 Places to get inspiration for new ads
 
1) Quora
2) Amazon Reviews
3) Facebook Ads library
4) Competitor’s website/Reviews
5) Facebook groups/Communities
 
Go where your ideal customers are already hanging out.

6/ Never start from scratch, Use different frameworks for creating ads.

- Pain, agitate, solve
- Hook, educate, sell
- Attention, interest, desire, action

Frameworks will allow you to churn out creatives really fast & you’ll never run out of creative ideas

7/ Suddenly your Facebook ads have started tanking?

Here’s how you can avoid this:

- Refresh your existing creatives with slight changes
- Test new creatives
- Change the Audience
- Improve your offer & landing page

Performance will be up & down at times, But you've to keep going

8/ Follow this structure to create Ads

(i) Research your target Audience
(ii) Note their problem/aspirations & Objection
(iii) Start your ads with their pain
(iv) Introduce your products
(v) Show them their aspired world
(vi) Handle the objection
(vii) Ask them to take action

Simple yet highly effective.

Two months ago today, at this time, innocent Jews were being murdered, raped, and mutilated at scale. 

Two months later and global Jew hatred is at an all time high. 

You tell me how that makes sense. Explain that to me without using the word antisemitism. 

Ya know, on October 8th, as I was trying to breathe, I said to myself, “This is just terrible but if there’s any silver lining here, any reason for hope or optimism, it’s that at least now the entire world will stand by our side as we do the work we need to do.”

I said to myself that there is no way, after the atrocities were clearly documented, that the world doesn’t stand with Israel. 

At least now the world will see the truth. At least now the world will know what we’ve known for decades, that this isn’t about land, but rather, about dead Jews. 

At least now, Israel will have global support. 

And, two months later, here we are with some of the most respected people in America declaring, with an evil smirk on their face, that calling for the genocide of Jews is valid and legit. 

Here we are, two months later with Jews being intimidated, beaten, and murdered on the streets.  

Here we are two months later, with Jews not being allowed to use a restroom because they’re Jewish. 

Two months later, and antisemitism is now not only tolerated, it is glorified and as widespread as ever before. It is now cool to hate Jews. 

Two months later, and two things are clear: 

- The world doesn’t like the Jews as much as we thought. 

- Jews love each other a lot more than we thought. 

If this is the reality after two months, what will the western world look like in two months from now? 

The emotions most Jews feel today include sadness, loneliness, despair, shock, concern, hopelessness, and deep fear for their future and the future of their loved ones. 

The last time Jews, as a nation, had all those emotions was in Europe 80 years ago. 

The world said they learned. The world said never again. The world reassured the Jews that they’d have their backs. 

The world lied and us Jews are devastated. 

So what is the silver lining now? That the Jewish nation is more united and stronger than we have been in a very very long time. 

We, as a people, are more connected to our heritage than we have been in many decades. 

If there’s any room for optimism, it’s that, this time, we don’t depend on the US to let us come into their country as we flee the persecution only to be turned away. 

This time, we have our own backs and the world is going to have to accept that. We are not giving them a choice. 

This time, we can fight back. And that’s exactly what we are doing and have no intention of stopping. 

Don’t like it? Too bad.
